official-title.#text:
To direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to establish a registry for certain toxic exposures, to
			 direct the Secretary to include certain information in the electronic
			 health records of veterans, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Veterans’ Toxic Wounds Research Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Veterans’ Toxic Wounds Research Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text:
Comprehensive program of research into toxic exposures encountered by veterans during military
			 service

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall establish a master registry of veterans who experienced
			 toxic exposures while serving in the Armed Forces.

text.#text: Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall establish each such registry using the
			 Clinical Case Registry of the
as a model.

text.#text:
The master registry established under paragraph (1) shall consist of the registries described in
			 paragraph (3). The
The registries described in this paragraph are registries for each of the following:
Agent Orange.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section
			 101(33) of title 38, United States Code

text.#text: Exposure to toxins relating to a deployment during the Persian Gulf War (as defined in

Exposure to toxins relating to a deployment during Operation Iraqi Freedom, Operation New Dawn,
			 Operation Enduring Freedom, or the Global War on Terror.

Exposure to toxins relating to a deployment to Bosnia, Somalia, the Philippines, or other locations
			 determined appropriate by the

Exposure to toxins relating to being stationed at a military installation potentially contaminated
			 by toxic substances, including Camp Lejeune, North Carolina, Fort
			 McClellan, Alabama, and such installations in Guam.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: determines appropriate.

text.#text: Any other toxic exposure the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall enter into an agreement with the National Academy of
			 Sciences to review published scientific information and studies on the
			 health effects of toxic exposures covered in a registry described in
			 subsection (a)(3). Under such agreement, the Institute of Medicine of the
			 National Academies shall submit to the

on a biennial basis a
			 report on toxic substance exposure-related illnesses. Such report shall
			 include—

text.#text: The

a review of all scientific studies and research on the association between toxic substance
			 exposures and specific diseases covered in such a registry, including the
			 level of association between such exposures and the specific diseases; and
recommendations for future research.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall enter into an agreement with
			 the National Academy of Sciences to review published scientific
			 information and studies on the health effects on the children and
			 grandchildren of veterans with toxic exposures covered in a registry
			 described in subsection (a)(3). Under such agreement, the Institute of
			 Medicine of the National Academies shall submit to the

on a
			 biennial basis a report on toxic substance exposure-related illnesses.
			 Such report shall include—

text.#text: In addition to the reviews under subsection (b), the

header.#text: Research into the effects of toxic exposure on second and third generations

text.#text:
a review of all scientific studies and research on the association between toxic substance
			 exposures and specific diseases covered in such a registry in such
			 children and grandchildren, including the level of association between
			 such exposures and the specific diseases; and
recommendations for future research.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall use the reviews conducted under subsections (b) and (c) to inform the decisions
			 made by the

with respect to selecting the research to be
			 conducted or funded by the
. The
shall submit to the
and the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Committees on Veterans’ Affairs of the House of
			 Representatives

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a report describing how the

used
			 such reviews to make such selections.

text.#text: The

header.#text:
Presumptions of service connection for illnesses associated with toxic exposures encountered by
			 veterans during military service

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, is amended by adding at the end the
			 following new section:

header.#text: Presumptions of service connection for illnesses associated with toxic exposures

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , and subject to

, each
			 illness, if any, described in paragraph (2) shall be considered to have
			 been incurred in or aggravated by service referred to in that paragraph,
			 notwithstanding that there is no record of evidence of such illness during
			 the period of such service.

text.#text: For purposes of
An illness referred to in paragraph (1) is any diagnosed or undiagnosed illness that—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
determines in regulations prescribed under this section to warrant a presumption of
			 service connection by reason of having a positive association with
			 exposure to a toxic substance covered in the master registry; and

text.#text: the

becomes manifest within the period, if any, prescribed in such regulations in a veteran who served
			 in the Armed Forces and by reason of such service experienced such
			 exposure.

For purposes of this subsection, a veteran who served in the Armed Forces in a location recognized
			 under the master registry as being a source of exposure and has an illness
			 described in paragraph (2) shall be presumed to have been exposed by
			 reason of such service unless there is conclusive evidence to establish
			 that the veteran was not so exposed by reason of such service.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: makes a determination described in subparagraph (B), the

shall
			 prescribe regulations providing that a presumption of service connection
			 is warranted for the illness covered by that determination for purposes of
			 this section.

text.#text: Whenever the

A determination referred to in subparagraph (A) is a determination based on sound medical and
			 scientific evidence that a positive association exists between—
the exposure of humans or animals to a toxic substance covered in the master registry; and
the occurrence of a diagnosed or un­di­ag­nosed illness in humans or animals.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall take into account—

text.#text: In making determinations for purposes of paragraph (1), the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: by the National Academy of Sciences under
; and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 2(b) of
			 the Veterans’ Toxic Wounds Research Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Veterans’ Toxic Wounds Research Act of 2014/s:2/ss:b

text.#text: the reports submitted to the
all other sound medical and scientific information and analyses available to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall take into consideration whether the results are
			 statistically significant, are capable of replication, and withstand peer
			 review.

text.#text: In evaluating any report, information, or analysis for purposes of making such determinations, the

An association between the occurrence of an illness in humans or animals and exposure to a toxic
			 substance covered in the master registry shall be considered to be
			 positive for purposes of this subsection if the credible evidence for the
			 association is equal to or outweighs the credible evidence against the
			 association.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
receives a report from the National
			 Academy of Sciences under
, the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 2(b) of the Veterans’ Toxic Wounds
			 Research Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Veterans’ Toxic Wounds Research Act of 2014/s:2/ss:b

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall determine whether or not a
			 presumption of service connection is warranted for each illness, if any,
			 covered by the report.

text.#text: Not later than 60 days after the date on which the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
determines under this subsection that a presumption of service connection is
			 warranted, the

shall, not later than 60 days after making the
			 determination, issue proposed regulations setting forth the
determination.

text.#text: If the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
determines under this subsection that a presumption of service connection is not
			 warranted, the

shall, not later than 60 days after making the
			 determination, publish in the Federal Register a notice of the
			 determination. The notice shall include an explanation of the scientific
			 basis for the determination.

text.#text: If the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall, not later than
			 60 days after publication of the notice under that subparagraph, issue
			 proposed regulations removing the presumption of service connection for
			 the illness.

text.#text:
If an illness already presumed to be service connected under this section is subject to a
			 determination under subparagraph (A), the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
issues any proposed regulations under
			 this subsection, the

shall issue final regulations. Such
			 regulations shall be effective on the date of issuance.

text.#text: Not later than 90 days after the date on which the

Whenever the presumption of service connection for an illness under this section is removed under
			 subsection (c)—

a veteran who was awarded compensation for the illness on the basis of the presumption before the
			 effective date of the removal of the presumption shall continue to be
			 entitled to receive compensation on that basis; and

a survivor of a veteran who was awarded dependency and indemnity compensation for the death of a
			 veteran resulting from the illness on the basis of the presumption before
			 that date shall continue to be entitled to receive dependency and
			 indemnity compensation on that basis.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 2 of the
			 Veterans’ Toxic Wounds Research Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Veterans’ Toxic Wounds Research Act of 2014/s:2

term.#tail: means the registry of veterans who experienced toxic exposures established by

text.#text: In this section, the term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: the following new item:

text.#text:
The table of sections at the beginning of such chapter is amended by inserting after the item
			 relating to

toc-entry.#text: 1119. Presumptions of service connection for illnesses associated with toxic exposures.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , the

shall ensure that the electronic health
			 record of each individual includes, at a minimum, the following
			 information:

text.#text: In implementing the electronic health record system of the

header.#text: Inclusion of certain information in electronic health records

text.#text: Whether the individual served in the Armed Forces.
The Armed Force in which the individual served.
The locations in which the individual was stationed or deployed to during such service.
The dates of such service.
The military occupational specialty of the individual.
The results of any tests or assessments of the individual regarding—
vision;
hearing;
hepatitis C;
HIV;
blood pressure;
cholesterol;
blood glucose test and diabetes information;
body mass index measurement;
bone density, as appropriate based on the age or sex of the individual;

cancer screenings (as appropriate based on the age, sex, race, or ethnicity of the individual)
			 for—
breast cancer;
colorectal cancer;
lung cancer;
prostate cancer; and
skin cancer;
preventive immunizations, if not current;
spirometry (for lung function);
smoking;
a mental health evaluation;
substance abuse; or

infectious diseases or parasites or other adverse health conditions endemic to where the individual
			 served while in the military.
